summary: "American Gothic" is a famous 1930 painting by Grant Wood, showing a farmer and his daughter in front of a house. It's one of the most recognized American paintings of the 20th century. Wood was inspired by a house in Eldon, Iowa, and the people he imagined living there. The farmer wears overalls with a suit jacket and carries a pitchfork, while his daughter (not his wife) wears a colonial-style apron. The models were Wood's sister and their dentist. The plants on the porch are the same as in Wood's portrait of his mother. The painting has been shown in Paris and London, its first trips outside the U.S.
title: American Gothic
